data.title: Use spawn instead of execFile and clean up running processes on process exit
data.body:
Fixes #13084

* Listen for the `exit` event on `process`, and kill the child process
* Unregister the event handler once the child process exits
* Switch to use `child_process.spawn` instead of `child_process.execFile` to avoid 100% CPU utilization on linux
* Ensure the environment is always set in `openPaths`

data.title: Cycling through many tabs does not show tab title when Atom is not full width of screen
data.body:
Atom version: 1.11.2
OS: Windows 7 64 SP1

As per
[https://discuss.atom.io/t/keyboard-shortcut-for-cycling-through-tabs/698](https://discuss.atom.io/t/keyboard-shortcut-for-cycling-through-tabs/698)

I added
```
'body':
  'ctrl-tab': 'pane:show-next-item'
  'ctrl-shift-tab': 'pane:show-previous-item'
```
to the config file.

Now when I have 10+ tabs open but Atom occupies half the screen and I cycle to a tab that is further down the line the pane does open correctly, however it does not show the tab title in the menu bar.

1. Like this I have to guess what file I am working on.
2. Also the path to the file has to be guessed like this as I cannot hover of the tab title and see the path.
3. I can see the filename and extension in the bottom left corner, however hovering over that link does not show the path, I have to click to have the path displayed plus the path is then copied to the clipboard. What if I already have other data in the clipboard that I like to copy from one file to another file.

How can I get Atom to also actively display the tab title, including the show full path on hover functionality, in the menu bar please?

Thank you for your help.

### Prerequisites

- Open some text-editor.
- Split editor into **two** by `cmd-k right`(or `cmd-k down` is OK), the point is **there are two panes in workspace**.
- Close pane item by `cmd-w`, then that pane is destroyed.
- The remaining editor on remaining pane don't get focused(expected: focus to remaining editor)

data.title: Soft tabs on a line after hard tabs advance to wrong position
data.body:
### Description

With soft tabs enabled I try to align text on the right of some other text. Since I am using soft tabs I expect the tab key to insert a number of spaces sufficient to move the cursor on the screen to the next tab stop.  This works if the line does not have any hard tabs on it already.  But it is wrong when there are hard tabs to the left of the cursor position on the same line.

This problem is surely caused by two different interpretations of the cursor column position.  One interpretation is the byte position in the buffer, and the other is the screen position as rendered.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new file.
2. Enable hard tabs, tab spacing 8.
3. Insert this text using the TAB key for <TAB>s:
```
     <TAB>buf =<TAB>nullptr;
     <TAB>a =<TAB>zero;
```
The zero and the nullptr should line up, as expected.
![With all tabs, text aligns correctly](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123908/20231736/cf05447a-a818-11e6-816c-da5e16b8d2fd.png)

4. Change the editor settings to soft tabs.
5. Delete the last tab just before `zero` and press <TAB> again.

**Expected behavior:** The 2nd line should have three spaces before `zero`, and the `zero` and `nullptr` text should be visually aligned on the screen.
![Expected behavior](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123908/20231747/dd43e15e-a818-11e6-9022-34f076957000.png)


**Actual behavior:** Only two spaces were inserted by the soft tab and the text does not align.
![Actual behavior](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123908/20231753/e988ead6-a818-11e6-839b-bcd34742c1b1.png)

### Versions

Running Ubuntu Linux 16.10 with Atom 1.11.2.

    $ atom --version
    Atom    : 1.11.2
    Electron: 0.37.8
    Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
    Node    : 5.10.0

data.title: Make `updateProcessEnv` async and add `core:loaded-shell-environment` activation hook
data.body:
Fixes #9406.
Fixes #13084.

When Atom is launched from the Dock, we invoke the user shell to retrieve environment variables that are assigned by their profile settings. However, we were doing so synchronously during startup, thus causing a [major slowdown](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9406) when opening Atom from the Dock and sometimes [hanging the startup process indefinitely](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13084).

With this pull request, we are changing `updateProcessEnv` into an asynchronous method. Packages that require shell environment variables to be assigned prior to activation can use the new `core:loaded-shell-environment` activation hook by putting the following snippet in `package.json`:

```json
{"activationHooks": ["core:loaded-shell-environment"]}
```

This will defer packages' activation until `process.env` has been updated with the user environment variables.

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: Atom 1.12.1 crashes on Ubuntu 16.04.1, refuses to start
data.body:
### Description

I have checked all the ways, started in safe mode, cleared up and removed `~/.atom` and `~/.config/Atom`. Atom crashes in a very early state, the message is:

```
$ atom -f .
[9575:1111/113317:ERROR:browser_main_loop.cc(231)] Running without the SUID sandbox! See https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/linux_suid_sandbox_development.md for more information on developing with the sandbox on.
```

It crashes right on startup and I cannot get it up and running at all.

### Steps to Reproduce

I did the following:

1. Had Atom already open
2. Update Atom (and Chrome) via the apt channel.
3. Switched back to Atom window.

Then Atom crashed, and refuses to open again.

### Versions

```
$ atom -v
Atom    : 1.12.1
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

Edit: In case it is relevant, I also have `google-chrome-stable` installed, version `54.0.2840.100`.

data.title: "Editor not responding" message is misleading
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
    * Well, I tried, but there's a lot of noise around "not responding"

Admittedly, some of these steps seemed pointless to me (safe mode, etc.) so I have checked them without actually performing them. However, I'm pretty sure it's the correct repo, and I did try to search for a pre-existing issue.

### Description

The "not responding" messages clearly states that an editor is not responding. To most people that would mean the current tab. However, if you click "closed editor" the whole entire window is closed. This, in my experience, breaks user expectation.

See screenshot in #9185.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Find a way to get a "not responding" message box up
2. Click on "Close"
3. Cry when it takes away everything you were working on

**Expected behavior:** Obviously it depends on what is actually unresponsive, but if, as it was in my case, it's because you decided to click on a minified JS file in the treeview (and after about 50ms you *knew* it was a bad idea), it'd be great to constrain the collateral damage to the currently open editor/tab/textbuffer (whatever it is) and only take that down (like Chrome does).

If it is a plugin that's running 'globally' or something similar, then of course, the window probably needs to burn.

But in the real world, I'm guessing it's not easy (if not impossible) to differentiate between the two (I bet syntax parsing/highlighting all happens in the big main thread as we're talking JS here right?). So, as a compromise, maybe just make the message say that the *window* will go bye-bye, not the "editor" (as it's not clear to normal users what "editor" means.

**Actual behavior:** The message says the *editor* is not responding, but the whole window goes if you click "close".

### Versions

```
❯ atom-beta --version
Atom    : 1.13.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

```
❯ apm-beta --version
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.9.3
```

OSX 10.11.6.

data.title: event.target no longer hold text-editor-element from 1.13.0-beta0
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?

* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

What `event.target` is holding was changed from Atom v1.13.0-beta0.
Which was hold text-editor-element in v1.12 but its changed to hold hidden-input-element.
So code like `event.target.getModel()` no longer work from v1.13.

Is this intentional change or accidential change?

### Steps to Reproduce

Define following command in `init.coffee`, and invoke it via command-pallette or via keymap(both results are same).

```coffeescript
atom.commands.add 'atom-text-editor', 'dev:show-event-target-of-text-editor-scope', (event) ->
  console.log event.target
  # following line throw exception from v1.13.0 since its no longer hold texxt-editor-element
  # console.log event.target.getModel()
```

- In atom v1.12.0: `<atom-text-editor class="editor vim-mode-plus normal-mode" tabindex="-1" data-grammar="source coffee" data-encoding="utf8"></atom-text-editor>`
- In atom v1.13.0-beta: `<input class="hidden-input" tabindex="-1" data-react-skip-selection-restoration="true" style="transform: translateZ(0px); top: 155px; left: 84px; width: 7px; height: 18px;">`

So package code `event.target.getModel()` no longer work from v1.13.0


### Versions

- atom-beta
```
$ atom-beta --version
Atom    : 1.13.0-beta1
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0
```

- apm-beta
```
$ apm-beta --version
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.6
git 2.7.4
```

data.title: Improper/slow rendering of Atom components w/ Compton display compositor
data.body:
### Description

When the Compton display compositor is enabled, Atom renders its UI considerably less responsively than when Compton is disabled. The procedure listed below is only for one particular example of this improper rendering, in which the menus are rendered late.
 * Note: While this bug does involve external software (Compton), said external software runs as expected with all other applications on my system, leading me to believe this is a bug in Atom (or Electron/etc) specifically.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start Atom (Normal or Safe Mode)
2. Click any item in top menubar (it will not render at this step)
3. Move mouse down from clicked menu (it will now render normally, as shown)
[http://imgur.com/77uDta4](url)
4. Move mouse back up to top menubar, then slide right to another item (it will partially remove the previously rendered menu, as shown)
[http://imgur.com/QndZ7Wf](url)
5. Move mouse down from clicked menu (it will now render normally, as shown)
[http://imgur.com/fWGEWA2](url)

**Expected behavior:**
* At step 2, the menu should be rendered immediately.
* At step 4, the new menu should be rendered immediately, replacing the previous menu.

### Versions

Ubuntu 16.04.1
Linux 4.4.0-47-generic

atom --version
* Atom    : 1.12.0
* Electron: 1.3.6
* Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
* Node    : 6.3.0

apm --version
* apm  1.12.9
* npm  3.10.5
* node 4.4.5
* python 2.7.12
* git 2.7.4
